summary: This is a letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorney, Jeffrey Pagliuca, to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the deadline for filing a motion under Federal Rule of Evidence 412. The letter argues that the motion, which concerns the admissibility of evidence of an alleged victim's sexual behavior, should be filed by November 15, 2021, as per the rule, citing recent government disclosures and the need for Maxwell to review the material.

persons.name: Jeffrey Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell who authored and submitted this letter to the court regarding the Rule 412 motion deadline.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The presiding judge in the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell to whom the letter is addressed.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the criminal case. The letter is filed on her behalf by her counsel, arguing for a specific deadline for her Rule 412 motion.

connections.description: Pagliuca is acting as defense counsel for Maxwell, as evidenced by him filing this letter on her behalf and referring to her as his client.
Nathan is the presiding judge over Maxwell's criminal case, as indicated by the case caption and the letter being addressed to her.
Pagliuca, as an attorney, is formally communicating with Judge Nathan regarding a procedural matter in the case.

events.title: Government Disclosure of 3500 Material
events.description: The government disclosed its 3500 material, including over 8,000 pages of testifying witness disclosures, and alerted defense to anticipated Rule 404(b) witnesses.

events.title: Maxwell Provided Government Disclosures
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell, who is in custody, was provided a copy of the government's disclosures in the late morning.

events.title: Proposed Rule 412 Motion Deadline
events.description: The date by which Ghislaine Maxwell's defense intends to file a motion under Federal Rule of Evidence 412, as argued for in this letter.

events.title: Motions in Limine Deadline
events.description: The court's pretrial scheduling order sets this date as the deadline for filing motions in limine, which the letter distinguishes from a Rule 412 motion.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
ISO East 10th Avenue Denver, Colorado 80203 (Law firm address)
keyFacts: The defense argues the deadline for filing a Rule 412 motion (regarding victim sexual behavior evidence) should be November 15, 2021, as per the federal rule, not an earlier date requested by the government.
The government recently disclosed over 8,000 pages of witness material and identified Rule 404(b) witnesses, which the defense needs time to review for potential Rule 412 evidence.
Ghislaine Maxwell was in custody and had only just received the government's disclosures on the morning of October 14, 2021, limiting her ability to consult with counsel.
The letter distinguishes a Rule 412 motion from a standard motion in limine, noting it is a substantive motion with its own specific procedures and deadlines.
